items.name: Jazz
items.description: An American art form emphasizing improvisation, syncopation, and blues influences.
items.details: Originated in New Orleans in the early 20th century. Combines African rhythms, European harmony, and American culture. Emphasizes individual expression and ensemble interaction.
examples: Cool Jazz: Miles Davis, John Coltrane

items.name: Blues
items.description: American music genre with roots in African American spirituals and work songs.
items.details: Characterized by 12-bar chord progression, blues scale, and expressive bending. Central to rock, jazz, and R&B. About expressing emotion and hardship.

items.name: Rock
items.description: Popular music genre characterized by guitars, strong rhythm, and youth culture.
items.details: Emerged in the 1950s combining blues, country, and pop. Emphasizes electric guitar, drums, and vocals. Extremely diverse with countless subgenres.
examples: Classic Rock: The Beatles, Led Zeppelin

items.name: Classical
items.description: Western art music tradition with written compositions and formal structure.
items.details: Spans from Renaissance to contemporary classical. Emphasizes complex harmony, orchestration, and structured forms like sonata and symphony.

items.name: Pop
items.description: Contemporary commercial music designed for mass appeal and radio play.
items.details: Emerged in the 1950s-60s. Characterized by catchy melodies, simple chord progressions, and relatable lyrics. Most commercially successful genre.

items.name: Hip Hop / Rap
items.description: Urban music genre emphasizing rhythmic spoken/sung lyrics over instrumental beats.
items.details: Originated in the 1970s Bronx. Core elements: DJing, rapping, breaking, and graffiti art. Rhythm and wordplay are essential.

items.name: Country
items.description: Genre rooted in American folk music, featuring storytelling and acoustic guitar.
items.details: Developed in rural America, emphasizing themes of heartbreak, working life, and relationships. Uses acoustic guitar, fiddle, and steel guitar prominently.

items.name: Folk
items.description: Traditional music of a culture, passed down through generations with acoustic instruments.
items.details: Varies widely by region and culture. Emphasizes tradition, community, and often social or political messages. Acoustic instruments dominate.
examples: American Folk: Woody Guthrie, Joan Baez
Celtic: Traditional Irish and Scottish music
Contemporary Folk: Bon Iver, Iron & Wine

items.name: Reggae
items.description: Caribbean music genre with a distinctive rhythm, strong bass, and spiritual themes.
items.details: Originated in Jamaica in the 1960s. Characterized by the offbeat skank rhythm and emphasis on the bass line. Often carries messages of peace and social consciousness.

items.name: Electronic / EDM
items.description: Music created primarily with electronic instruments and digital production.
items.details: Encompasses house, techno, trance, drum and bass, and many subgenres. Emphasizes rhythm, repetition, and synthesized sounds. Essential in modern dance culture.

items.name: Metal
items.description: Genre featuring distorted guitars, powerful vocals, and intense instrumentation.
items.details: Emerged from rock in the 1970s. Characterized by high volume, heavily distorted guitars, and often aggressive themes. Extremely diverse subgenres.
examples: Heavy Metal: Black Sabbath, Iron Maiden

items.name: R&B / Soul
items.description: Genre emphasizing soulful vocals, smooth grooves, and emotional expression.
items.details: Rooted in African American music. Combines elements of gospel, blues, and jazz. Known for vocal prowess, emotional depth, and sophisticated production.
examples: Classic Soul: Marvin Gaye, Aretha Franklin

items.name: Funk
items.description: Groove-based music with strong emphasis on bass and syncopated rhythm.
items.details: Emerged in the 1960s as fusion of soul, jazz, and R&B. All about the groove and making people dance. Heavy, tight rhythm section is essential.

items.name: Latin / Salsa
items.description: Music genres from Latin America and Hispanic cultures with distinctive rhythmic patterns.
items.details: Includes salsa, mambo, cha-cha, rumba, and many others. Characterized by complex polyrhythmic patterns, brass sections, and dance-oriented grooves.

items.name: Gospel
items.description: Spiritual music rooted in Christian African American tradition with powerful vocals.
items.details: Emphasizes vocal prowess, emotional expression, and spiritual themes. Often features call-and-response, hand claps, and organ accompaniment.

items.name: Ambient
items.description: Atmospheric, texture-based music designed to create mood rather than dominate attention.
items.details: Focuses on timbre and soundscapes rather than structure. Often used as background music for relaxation or meditation. Can be purely electronic or mixed with acoustic elements.

items.name: Indie / Alternative
items.description: Music produced outside major label systems, often with experimental or unconventional approaches.
items.details: Emphasis on artistic control and authenticity over commercial appeal. Highly diverse in sound but unified by independent spirit. Emerged from 1980s underground.
examples: Indie Rock: The Strokes, Arctic Monkeys
Indie Pop: Tame Impala, Mac DeMarco

items.name: Punk
items.description: Fast, aggressive, short-song-focused rock music with DIY ethos and political edge.
items.details: Emerged in mid-1970s as reaction against progressive rock. Emphasizes raw energy, simple chords, and often carries social or political messages.

items.name: Disco
items.description: Dance music genre with strong beat, bass, and funk elements, designed for dancing.
items.details: Dominated 1970s with synthesizers, drum machines, and emphasis on the 4/4 beat. Known for vocal harmonies, lush orchestration, and high energy.

items.name: World / Ethnic Music
items.description: Traditional and contemporary music from diverse cultures around the globe.
items.details: Encompasses music from Africa, Asia, Middle East, and beyond. Often features traditional instruments and cultural practices specific to regions.
examples: Middle Eastern: Oud players, Sufi music

items.name: Ska
items.description: Upbeat genre combining reggae rhythms with punk/rock energy and horn sections.
items.details: Originated in Jamaica in the late 1950s. Combines offbeat guitar skank with horns and fast tempo. Known for dance-oriented, uplifting sound.

items.name: Grunge
items.description: Rock genre blending punk, metal, and hard rock with angst-filled lyrics.
items.details: Emerged from Seattle in the 1980s-90s. Characterized by distorted guitars, powerful drumming, and emotional, often dark lyrics. Anti-establishment attitude.
